revisions:
[{'created': '2015-01-05 01:06:10.000000000', 'message': 'Lock Fedora-based image to specific versions

This prevents unexpected breakage on new Fedora release.

Fedora 20 is the last release known to work. Images based on Fedora 21
are currently broken as they lack required packages such as iproute.
Support for Fedora 21 is on the way and will follow soon once all images
have been verified.

Change-Id: I849732147302eaf00d864d6b5093ff6ac006f496
'}]
commit_message:
Lock Fedora-based image to specific versions

This prevents unexpected breakage on new Fedora release.

Fedora 20 is the last release known to work. Images based on Fedora 21
are currently broken as they lack required packages such as iproute.
Support for Fedora 21 is on the way and will follow soon once all images
have been verified.

Change-Id: I849732147302eaf00d864d6b5093ff6ac006f496

commit_message:
Skip failing execute tests when using /tmp noexec

test_retry_on_failure and test_no_retry_on_success from
ExecuteTestCase are failing when running system with /tmp noexec.
These tests should be skipped in this case.

Related-bug: #1359463
Change-Id: I32fa8f90a6292229bd23eec6d648fab617e59ec3

commit_message:
Implements k8s resource creation/updating with data

Now kube_utils.py supports creation/updating from k8s resource data.
User will be able to updload pod/service/replication_controller data to
create or update resource.

Change-Id: I98f7ab2eab7ac9e68c4e4a313a61f7d39b7596b2

commit_message:
Add master endpoint support to kube_utils.py

kubeutils.py support k8s master endpoint url to connect remote k8s cluster.
In this change, some method signatures are refactored for future works.

Change-Id: Ie065abeef3c65ea429b799a932fe39d868fabcbf

commit_message:
Added deprecation notice for the RBD driver configuration option

In the RBD driver section, added a note about volume_tmp_dir option being deprecated from the rbd driver
and replaced by  image_conversion_dir

Change-Id: I2ae271039788f8f138dc6c999a17cae36686bfce
backport: none
Partial-Bug: #1406183

commit_message:
Fixed the document bug for huawei storage drivers

Update document for huawei storage drivers that have been merged in juno.
The following content will be amended:
*The name of our driver have been changed from HVS to 18000;
*Removed the configuration for Dorado.

Change-Id: I66ac33052dc8b3c7d43bef09e7d96d4e8e14920b
Closes-Bug: #1406227

Update the README to reflect new additions to kolla

Added the new containers we are supporting.
Kubernetes has updated and kubecfg was replaced with kubectl.

commit_message:
Build up reconstructor with correct node selection

The reconstructor does not operate on the full
node list for any given partition, only on its
left and right partners.  This is an incremental
change to the ongoing WIP on the reconstructor.

blueprint ec-reconstructor
Change-Id: I6e9ec5fa1f7ce56ba3211034090dd908e079f91d

commit_message:
Fixed the document bug for huawei storage drivers

Update document for huawei storage drivers that have been merged in icehouse.
The following content will be amended:
*The name of our driver have been changed from HVS to 18000;
*Removed the configuration for Dorado.

Change-Id: I05bbe35953afa8b660b77c09f00c904c22e2740b
Closes-Bug: #1406226

(1 comment)

Looks good. I made a real minor point about the exceptions in there. Also the auth for pager duty is in the notification.address? I think documentation specifying that would be good, though that probably fits in with the api docs. You will of course have to change the mysql schema to handle this and for completeness should update the api docs also. I'm assuming the api itself can handle the new notification type if not that needs updating also.

Though not necessarily something to address in this code review as I was reading through it I was wondering at what point do we refactor the entire thing so the notifications can be added in their own classes and modules? It isn't so bad right now but add a few more notification types and things will start to get a bit cluttered. Additionally with all of those notification types in many situations not all will be used so the ability to handle notifications that come through for unconfigured notification types will need to be added."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-01-05 23:51:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified-1

commit_message:
VMware: ensure that configdrive file is accessible after resize

When a instance is resized the VM is clone. The cloning does not
copy the config drive. This break if the instance is on a host that
does not have access to the original datastore.

Closes-bug: #1407050

Change-Id: Ic331d8a8a9e7b7236f4a8f89a9c28c31d71dd9cd

use the correct datatsore for resizing the root disk. This worked
due to the fact that all of the datastores are in the same
datacenter.

The patch also moves the resize code to the correct place where
we can use the flavor instead of extracting it from the instance.

commit_message:
VMware: fix root disk resize bug

Commit 7ae506a4b1829fbd8cbecc0a6b267f76230face7 did not
use the correct datatsore for resizing the root disk. This worked
due to the fact that all of the datastores are in the same
datacenter.

The patch also moves the resize code to the correct place where
we can use the flavor instead of extracting it from the instance.

Change-Id: Ib6f2f46e8eb9c445eb22c676fb17f6a1f1d68144
Closes-bug: #1407438

Johannes, updates in latest patch set clear up any confusion for me.  I was making this more complicated than it really was.  Calling out the db expand/migrate/contract commands more explicitly makes it more understandable.  Looks good to me now.'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2014-06-27 00:53:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'd like to suggest that we look to using Alembic's engine totally.   Discussion on IRC has led us to the only blocker being Alembic's lack of SQLite migration support; this is certainly something that can be added, more or less ported from Migrate's approach if needed and has been on the roadmap for a long time: https://bitbucket.org/zzzeek/alembic/issue/21/column-renames-not-supported-on-sqlite

Also, I'm not seeing in this document the mechanism by which migrate would separate migrations into these three streams, would this involve three separate series of migration files as well as database version ids?    I'd also note that Alembic has roadmapped a series of improvements that will allow for seamless maintenance of multiple simultaneous branches as well as multiple directories, see https://bitbucket.org/zzzeek/alembic/issue/124/multiple-versions-directories and https://bitbucket.org/zzzeek/alembic/issue/167/multiple-heads-branch-resolution-support.

As I am now a fulltime Openstack developer my plate is open to address these alembic features fully if this is where the need is focused."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2014-06-27 01:44:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

alembic's autogenerate engine is lacking right now.

Some parts of the schema aren't handled at all (constraints as an example).

It doesn't do any dependency sorting. As a result it can attempt to create tables in the wrong order for foreign keys.

Also, there are problems with the way tables are created. For instance, there is a CREATE TABLE statement with columns and constraints (foreign keys) but indexes are added after the CREATE TABLE.

This interacts poorly with MySQL for instance, where it will autocreate indexes for foreign keys. Explicitly creating the indexes afterwards will end up with an error because of the implicitly created indexes.

There were some other problems I ran into as well that I can't remember off the top of my head.

That said, the DDL generation is pretty good especially considering I don't want to reimplement all of that for MySQL, PostgreSQL and soon DB2 :)

I'm not against using alembic for all of the schema synchronization in the future, but all of the fixes were a large set of dependencies that I didn't want to impose on this blueprint right now.

Also, there is still only one stream of migrations. You can think of this blueprint as a hybrid between declarative and imperative.

We use a declarative model for most of the schema changes and then imperative (sqlalchemy-migrate) for the rest."}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2014-06-27 02:15:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

>  Some parts of the schema aren't handled at all (constraints as an example).

which constraints are we referring to, and are you referring to the "autogenerate" feature alone?  All constraints are supported except that some are not part of autogenerate, but as the documentation states, these are also all on the roadmap.

> It doesn't do any dependency sorting. As a result it can attempt to create tables in the wrong order for foreign keys.

I need some education on this feature.  If a migration states this:

    def upgrade():
         create_table('foo', ... columns ...)

         create_table('bat', ... columnns... )

         create_table('bar', ... columnns...)

are you saying that the migration engine should batch these commands up, not invoking any SQL, and then later it should hit some point at which it sorts them via foreign key order and then execute them ina batch ?  I've used migrate a lot, I never was aware it had any such capability?   

Or do you simply mean, that one can say:

    def upgrade():
        Table('foo', metadata, ... columns ...)

        Table('bar', metadata, ... columns ...)

        Table('bat', metadata, ... columns ...)

        metadata.create_all(op.bind)

?

The above is a feature of SQLAlchemy itself, not Migrate.  It is just as valid in Alembic.

> Also, there are problems with the way tables are created. For instance, there is a CREATE TABLE statement with columns and constraints (foreign keys) but indexes are added after the CREATE TABLE.
> This interacts poorly with MySQL for instance, where it will autocreate indexes for foreign keys. Explicitly creating the indexes afterwards will end up with an error because of the implicitly created indexes.

Then I'm puzzled how Migrate supports this as it relies upon SQLAlchemy to emit DDL.  Migrate would have had to added its own extension. 

There have been issues reported regarding Alembic + autogenerate plus it including MySQL's implicit indexes as explicit instructions which need to be manually removed and these have been fixed, see http://alembic.readthedocs.org/en/latest/changelog.html#change-afcf3a95ca0bfe87c9371ba9bef1d750 and http://alembic.readthedocs.org/en/latest/changelog.html#change-08832fb2cc714d02fe5132ef43a318f5.   Additional bugs will be fixed immediately as they always have.   


> I'm not against using alembic for all of the schema synchronization in the future, but all of the fixes were a large set of dependencies that I didn't want to impose on this blueprint right now.

that's entirely valid and I would need a full list of issues and features needed in Alembic, for which I can give you a timeline when they will be available - from there you can make the determination as to if this blueprint should wait for that or not.'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2014-06-27 02:24:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

oh, regarding tables in dependency order, I missed the word "autogenerate".  The library does support this, the autogen feature when it gen's the create tables are sorted based on existing foreign keys.   Looking at the code, this might be lacking on the remove side.   I can look into existing tests to see to what extent we are ensuring this order but again, this is supported, if it isn't working, it will be fixed.  thanks!'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2014-06-27 02:51:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

You can look at the 216_havana.py migration to see how we have dealt with it in the past. It basically creates all of the table (without foreign keys), then creates all of the indexes and then creates all of the foreign keys.

The blueprint would make the 216 migration unnecessary since it would all be created automatically by comparing the empty DB to the model and create the tables in the necessary order.

My implementation of the blueprint does something similar to the 216 migration by creating new tables without any indexes or constraints and then adding the indexes and constraints afterwards. It's one of a few workarounds I have right now.

How does alembic.autogenerate deal with server-side type aliasing? For instance, MySQL converts BOOLEAN to TINYINT(1) which ended up causing me some problems. I never got far enough with alembic to see if it considers the columns different or not."}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2014-06-27 15:46:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> You can look at the 216_havana.py migration to see how we have dealt with it in the past. It basically creates all of the table (without foreign keys), then creates all of the indexes and then creates all of the foreign keys.

I've looked at 216.  It appears that some of the FKs are done in this style, others are not.  In any case this is all manually placed into the file.  Generating all the FKs as separate constraints after all tables would be a way that Alembic can not have to worry about table create order - the fact that SQLAlchemy/migrate/alembic work in the other way right now is kind of historical artifact at this point, that's just the way it's always been done.  Alembic / Migrate etc. could also support doing it the other way with some modification (assuming Migrate doesn't have this option already).

> The blueprint would make the 216 migration unnecessary since it would all be created automatically by comparing the empty DB to the model and create the tables in the necessary order.

What I'm not following is after the comparison, are we generating a migration file like the 216_havana.py file, just automatically (e.g. a large autogenerate)?  Or are we rolling up auto-detected migrations in-process and then running them directly?

If the latter option, this is fine for coarse-grained changes like tables being created.  If OTOH it intends to take place for fine-grained migrations, that is, additions/drops of columns, changes in column types, I am more skeptical that this can be performed without manual intervention, however this depends on how the schema comparison is being performed.

If the comparison is the way Alembic does it, that is, SQLAlchemy metadata compared to structures reflected from an existing database, there's a lot of problems with this approach.   For one thing, I've not figured out how one can discern between a column that had its name changed, versus one column being dropped and another one added.   Another, fine-grained migrations have limitless behaviors that are always expanding.   Things like the size of a VARCHAR or the elements within an ENUM can change, does Migrate have in place change detection functions for all of SQLAlchemy's supported datatypes?   It's also often hit or miss comparing the state of things like server-side defaults, for which the database's reporting of the default's structure can vary from what the SQLAlchemy representation was originally.

> My implementation of the blueprint does something similar to the 216 migration by creating new tables without any indexes or constraints and then adding the indexes and constraints afterwards. It's one of a few workarounds I have right now.

I'm looking at the index logic in 216 and it refers often to "MySQL diffs" as the rationale for this highly specific CREATE INDEX ordering.  Where can I look to get more background on that rationale and how MySQL diffs are used ?

> How does alembic.autogenerate deal with server-side type aliasing? For instance, MySQL converts BOOLEAN to TINYINT(1) which ended up causing me some problems. I never got far enough with alembic to see if it considers the columns different or not.

Alembic has backend-specific dialects where comparison rules can be added.  In the case of MySQL, if it receives a SQLAlchemy Boolean type object and sees that the database reports a TINYINT, no change is needed.   At the moment, this particular rule is not implemented within Alembic as we leave type comparison off by default and leave it to users to implement user-specific comparison rules. But this omission is only due to Alembic's status as a one-person project that seeks to provide user-expansion infrastructure first before trying to implement every possible feature directly.

Ultimately, the problem of type comparison is one that should be rolled into SQLAlchemy itself and implemented by dialects and datatypes directly.   This would be a straightforward but very arduous feature to add.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2014-06-27 16:38:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I'm not sure if it's clear enough, but the blueprint does point it out that it only automatically applies a subset of schema changes. It leaves the rest to be manually applied as part of sqlalchemy-migrate migrations as they always have been done.

Since the main goal of this blueprint is to optimize the deployment process, it doesn't need to be perfect and support every schema change possible, or even the schema changes that nova has even used in the past. Automating the "easy" stuff still gets a huge win during deployments but also for maintaining and writing migrations in the future.

Column renames are the only tricky part I've run across since they look like a new column to the synchronizer. Thanks for reminding me about those since I should probably add some documentation about them. There's a couple of possible options I've thought of:

- We can let the expand phase automatically create the new column (since it looks like a new column to it) and then let the migration drop the column and then rename the old one. The contract phase would do nothing since the old column name doesn't exist anymore. It's not perfect, but as far as hacks go, it's pretty clean (one extra line).

- Alternatively, we can add a new class attribute in the model to define column renames and the synchronizer can use that to better understand that the column should not be added.

I'm leaning towards the former to start with since column renames have historically been rare for nova and the workaround is easy and not too bad.

I'm certainly not against doing something smarter in the future. The goal with this blueprint is to get the easiest and highest impact stuff done first. Then iterate on it.

Also, in case I didn't make it clear before, I would really like to lean on alembic and SQLAlchemy for as much as possible in the future. I have an implementation that does effectively the same thing alembic.autogenerate does, but in a way that works for nova (for instance, it only handles type aliasing for the types Nova actually uses). I don't want to maintain this code long term and I believe the concepts have value for other projects so I'd certainly like to get alembic and SQLAlchemy to the point where it can replace my code.'}, {'account_id': 4573, 'date': '2014-07-01 23:01:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I'm not sure what's the exact relationship of the schema changes and additive migration, but I assume they are in fact   related. Would it be possible to talking about this?

I'd think if we take this way, the implementation of the migration will be complex than current implementation, some description of how to achieve some common changes will be helpful, and it will also make sure the design will meet those scenario. At least from one of my failed experiment, it's not easy to achieve additive migration."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-07-01 23:01:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Verified

I've pushed up a new version of the spec.

Most of the changes are around keeping the existing sqlalchemy-migrate path in parallel, like we discussed previously.

It's probably the safer choice, but it does add an extra dependency on data migrations. This has to wait until those are completely done outside of sqlalchemy-migrate.

Also, there is one other thing our migrations have done that isn't technically schema or data migrations, populating rows in the instance_types table.

The 216 migration will insert some default instance types. We'll need to decide on a story since implementing this spec will not keep that behavior. I'm currently thinking we just document that new installs will need to create instance types manually since that will no longer occur as part of creating the database."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2014-11-26 19:12:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Online Schema Changes

Make schema changes execute online (ie while services are running) when
safely and semantically possible. This will allow operators to reduce the
amount of downtime currently required during deploys by running most
database schema changes when services are running.

Change-Id: Ibbab7cb29911d52b57c467c6bfbc5876d1102e79

[{'created': '2015-01-02 07:29:20.000000000', 'message': 'Fix wrong description of uuid and port parameters

The current description of the uuid and port paramaters for server create state
that uuid is for nova-network and port is for neutron. In reality, uuid is for
the network uuid and port is for specifying an already existing port-id.

Change-Id: I1bf3b9d95b526c49628bb7dc715f47dcdcd4152b
Closes-Bug: #1407031
'}]
commit_message:
Fix wrong description of uuid and port parameters

The current description of the uuid and port paramaters for server create state
that uuid is for nova-network and port is for neutron. In reality, uuid is for
the network uuid and port is for specifying an already existing port-id.

Change-Id: I1bf3b9d95b526c49628bb7dc715f47dcdcd4152b
Closes-Bug: #1407031

commit_message:
Fix a wrong response code in Neutron API Reference

Fix the response code for "update subnet" in Neutron API Reference
from 201 to 200.

Change-Id: Iea72123879654bd187828cf746c5c9b14b84038d
Closes-Bug: #1405720

commit_message:
hardware: fix numa topology from image meta data

The behavior of the method numa_get_constraints is to get a dict of
image properties to determine whether a NUMA topology has been defined
in the image.
We currently pass to this method a dict of image information or sometimes only
a dict of properties of the image.

We should always pass the dict of image information

Change-Id: If023bfa766f67288699c17f5b5daabdc24d03ea2
Closes-Bug: #1404839

'}, {'created': '2015-01-05 00:35:23.000000000', 'message': 'Fix py3k issues

1) Module urllib2 is missed in Python 3, so it should be replaced by other
   http lib. "requests" is good library for such stuff, which supports both
   Python 2.* and Python 3.*

2) Function 'rally.common.utils.parse_docstring' uses built-in function
   'filter'. This function returns different types in Python 2.* and
   Python 3.*. Since results are used as a list, 'filter' should be replaced
   by list comprehension.

3) Extend H330 hacking rule to chech 'dict.iterkeys()', 'dict.itervalues()'
   and 'dict.iterlist()'. Also, fixed all places, which are failed in terms
   of this rule.

4) Function object does not have 'func_code' attribute in Python 3
   (it was renamed to '__code__'), so check of python version with proper
   code added to 'tests.unit/test_docstrings' module.

Tests, which are successfully finished in Python 34:
 tests.unit.aas
 tests.unit.db
 tests.unit.doc
 tests.unit.fixtures
 tests.unit.objects
 tests.unit.orchestrator
 tests.unit.rally_jobs
 tests.unit.ui

Closes-Bug: #1405919

Change-Id: Icc42e220ac3f15ae6c838a4698b3c9578177513c

commit_message:
Fix py3k issues

1) Module urllib2 is missed in Python 3, so it should be replaced by other
   http lib. "requests" is good library for such stuff, which supports both
   Python 2.* and Python 3.*

2) Function 'rally.common.utils.parse_docstring' uses built-in function
   'filter'. This function returns different types in Python 2.* and
   Python 3.*. Since results are used as a list, 'filter' should be replaced
   by list comprehension.

3) Extend H330 hacking rule to chech 'dict.iterkeys()', 'dict.itervalues()'
   and 'dict.iterlist()'. Also, fixed all places, which are failed in terms
   of this rule.

4) Function object does not have 'func_code' attribute in Python 3, but
   '__code__' attribute exist in both Python 2 and Python 3

Also, 3 tests are broken due to new release(1.6.0) of oslo.config, so we
need to skip them to unblock our gates until new version of oslo.config will
be released with appropriate fix.

Closes-Bug: #1405919

Change-Id: Icc42e220ac3f15ae6c838a4698b3c9578177513c

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-12-11 17:42:51.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor common l2pop DB code into single method

On the DB layer the queries used to fetch DVR and non DVR port details
are almost the same, so extracted the logic to a common method that gets
the model to query as an argument, and the filtering for the DVR ports
is still done in the DVR method.

Change-Id: I5d936c6e73033e8b6500110015b5e777ecca6381
'}]
commit_message:
Refactor common l2pop DB code into single method

On the DB layer the queries used to fetch DVR and non DVR port details
are almost the same, so extracted the logic to a common method that gets
the model to query as an argument, and the filtering for the DVR ports
is still done in the DVR method.

Change-Id: I5d936c6e73033e8b6500110015b5e777ecca6381

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-01-06 11:42:06.000000000', 'message': 'Fix newline issue in sshd_config

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/143151/ introduced a problem where
under certain circumstances MaxSessions 500 would be appended to the
last line of sshd_config rather than added as a new line.

This patch fixes that. It also means that in normal situations an extra
new line is inserted, but that is inconsequential.

Change-Id: Ib3d9e86b6434f686eba1cbea08b5ee8a8cb74a50
Closes-Bug: #1404343
'}]
commit_message:
Fix newline issue in sshd_config

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/143151/ introduced a problem where
under certain circumstances MaxSessions 500 would be appended to the
last line of sshd_config rather than added as a new line.

This patch fixes that. It also means that in normal situations an extra
new line is inserted, but that is inconsequential.

Change-Id: Ib3d9e86b6434f686eba1cbea08b5ee8a8cb74a50
Closes-Bug: #1404343

commit_message:
print error when no match mapping found in check_segment_for_agent

error print when no match PHYSICAL_NETWORK mapping found in function
check_segment_for_agent for OVS and linuxbridge mechanism driver.

Change-Id: I58c43328f0512de25720871fc51c79f074493cdf
Closes-Bug: #1404962

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2015-01-06 11:57:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

Just did some research on sqlalchemy.ext.mutable.  It seems strange that we treat both LongText and Json as MutableDict.   Though it makes sense to associate Json with MutableDict, associating LongText to MutableDict is not reasonable.

When we look back into our data models, we found that some data types are strange as well.  For example, SoftwareConfig.config is declared to be a STRING in property schema, but in DB models, it is declared to be a Json.  Maybe we could have used LongText there.  But due to the improper associate_with, we are making the code not easy to be understood...

So, I withdraw my +1 here.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-01-06 13:53:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+2

commit_message:
Remove MutableDict realization

We already use SQLAlchemy 0.9.7 so we can use MutableDict from
SQLAlchemy directly and remove it's realization from Heat code

Change-Id: Ib3bd706fa0103db4363563b6b9882a98cf75cff5

commit_message:
Use oslo.config generator

Replace usage of old incubator configuration generator by the
oslo.config tool.

tools/config/generate_sample.sh has been replaced by tox -egenconfig.

heat_integrationtests/generate_sample.sh has been replaced by
oslo-config-generator
--config-file=heat_integrationtests/config-generator.conf

Change-Id: I6d95df203b556c8ec2088d40a446427f7087b9a7

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-01-02 17:23:06.000000000', 'message': 'Gracefully fail to delete nonempty S3 Bucket

The AWS::S3::Bucket resource is susceptible to bug #1406263
as it is backed by the same Swift container - on deleting non empty
container it produces incomprehensible truncated message.

This patch uses the same logic as it is now in OS::Swift::Container
resource, making the reason of failure clear. The error message is made
to resemble the error produced by this resource on real AWS
in the same usage scenario.

Change-Id: Ib67c55f010613c8edb913bb264d3cc4a7315d847
Related-Bug: #1406263
'}]
commit_message:
Gracefully fail to delete nonempty S3 Bucket

The AWS::S3::Bucket resource is susceptible to bug #1406263
as it is backed by the same Swift container - on deleting non empty
container it produces incomprehensible truncated message.

This patch uses the same logic as it is now in OS::Swift::Container
resource, making the reason of failure clear. The error message is made
to resemble the error produced by this resource on real AWS
in the same usage scenario.

Change-Id: Ib67c55f010613c8edb913bb264d3cc4a7315d847
Related-Bug: #1406263

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-12-15 11:15:14.000000000', 'message': 'Fix neutron hang for IPv6 allocation pool update

While rebuilding IPAllocationPools, Neutron is using netaddr.iter_iprange
(a generator that produces IPAddress objects). For an IPv6 subnet, this is
a costly operation and is causing Neutron Server to hang. This patch
addresses the issue by replacing netaddr.iter_iprange with netaddr.IPRange
which provides the same functionality while calculating the IPSets.

Closes-Bug: #1401751
Change-Id: I2287e5348aab82e39cf1b6e2884d08237a09b06d
'}]
commit_message:
Fix neutron hang for IPv6 allocation pool update

While rebuilding IPAllocationPools, Neutron is using netaddr.iter_iprange
(a generator that produces IPAddress objects). For an IPv6 subnet, this is
a costly operation and is causing Neutron Server to hang. This patch
addresses the issue by replacing netaddr.iter_iprange with netaddr.IPRange
which provides the same functionality while calculating the IPSets.

Closes-Bug: #1401751
Change-Id: I2287e5348aab82e39cf1b6e2884d08237a09b06d

subject: Removed spurious check for ip version

commit_message:
Removed spurious check for ip version

We may assume that _add_ingress_ra_rule() receives only RA (=IPv6)
ports, so no need to check IP version one more time.

The corresponding IP version filter is already applied in
_select_ra_ips_for_network_ids().

Change-Id: Ibde56a2eb32eed468defdd02a44cc3360ce82e53

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-01-05 22:50:43.000000000', 'message': 'Add a new hook for gathering extra logs

post_test_hook is only run when $GATE_RETVAL is 0, so when
the gate_hook fails, we need another hook similar to post_test_hook
which can be used to gather logs. There are 32 existing post_test_hook(s)
currently and it would be impossible to predict their behavior if
we try to reuse the post_test_hook by ignoring GATE_RETVAL as was done
in Id9a6aa72a8dee69cf1e73789281fd63385cfe12c

Change-Id: Ib539ef5eab697fee642eb0be42f2ff4b41c95687
'}]
commit_message:
Add a new hook for gathering extra logs

post_test_hook is only run when $GATE_RETVAL is 0, so when
the gate_hook fails, we need another hook similar to post_test_hook
which can be used to gather logs. There are 32 existing post_test_hook(s)
currently and it would be impossible to predict their behavior if
we try to reuse the post_test_hook by ignoring GATE_RETVAL as was done
in Id9a6aa72a8dee69cf1e73789281fd63385cfe12c

Change-Id: Ib539ef5eab697fee642eb0be42f2ff4b41c95687

commit_message:
Move 3 Fujitsu ETERNUS DX related file

Since there are three volume driver files relating to Fujitsu ETERNUS DX in cinder.volume.drivers,
I make 'fujitsu' directory at cinder.volume.drivers and I move these files to the directory.

Closes-Bug #1402349
https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1402349

Change-Id: I2fbbdf2a9d9c97ce511d9dfbbeca8b51e5213c0d

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-12-23 00:48:46.000000000', 'message': 'Enable the "not-callable" pylint check

This change enables the "not-callable" pylint check, after disabling a
few cases where the alert triggers but the usage was intended (defining
decorators).

A real syntax error was also caught in vmware advanced services plugin -
fixed in a separate change.

Change-Id: I09ad929902509018fe7183a15b784601c36b6196
Related-Bug: #1356224
'}, {'created': '2014-12-30 01:39:39.000000000', 'message': 'Enable the "not-callable" pylint check

This check catches attempts to call variables that pylint believes are
not functions.  A trivial example would be:

    # Trivial example caught by this check:
    foo = dict()
    print foo('bar')  # <- oops, meant foo['bar']

This change enables the "not-callable" pylint check, after disabling a
few cases where the alert triggers but the usage was intended (defining
decorators).

Change-Id: I09ad929902509018fe7183a15b784601c36b6196
Related-Bug: #1356224
'}, {'created': '2014-12-31 04:30:10.000000000', 'message': 'Enable the "not-callable" pylint check

This check catches attempts to call variables that pylint believes are
not functions.  A trivial example would be:

    # Trivial example caught by this check:
    foo = dict()
    print foo('bar')  # <- oops, meant foo['bar']

commit_message:
Enable the "not-callable" pylint check

This check catches attempts to call variables that pylint believes are
not functions.  A trivial example would be:

    # Trivial example caught by this check:
    foo = dict()
    print foo('bar')  # <- oops, meant foo['bar']

This change enables the "not-callable" pylint check, after disabling a
few cases where the alert triggers but the usage was intended (defining
decorators).

Change-Id: I09ad929902509018fe7183a15b784601c36b6196
Related-Bug: #1356224

Thanks qiming, I think implement the 'InstanceId' for launchconfiguration is another bp, I'll implement it, and the method is to override any properties from the instance by specifying them in the launch configuration. But for AWS::AutoScaling::AutoScalingGroup we can only specify the 'InstanceId' but not 'LaunchConfigurationName', the method is to store the properties as the resource_data, or any good idea for this?"}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2014-10-27 06:46:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Well, I was suggesting to consider supporting InstanceId in both LaunchConfigration and AutoScalingGroup in one work.  If we have a unified way of handling 'InstanceId', we won't have to struggle when dealing with operations like stack update.  For example, is it possible to build an (invisible) LaunchConfiguration out of an InstanceId specified, and then use it internally?"}, {'account_id': 8289, 'date': '2014-10-27 10:03:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I saw the aws doc, aws implements this in the way you said, if specify 'InstanceId' for AWS::AutoScaling::AutoScalingGroup, a new launch configuration is first created and then associated with the Auto Scaling group. I thought about it, also we should store the launch configuration somewhere and I think resource_data is a good choice, and I think the properties dict is enough. We can make a public function to get the instance properties for AWS::AutoScaling::AutoScalingGroup and AWS::AutoScaling::LaunchConfiguration."}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2014-10-27 11:54:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

tiantian, I am all for persisting resource data, though I'm not quite sure using resource_data is the right solution.  The sole purpose of having LaunchConfiguration resource type is to support auto-scaling groups.  If a LaunchConfiguration needs to be derived from an InstanceId, why not just do it -- just treat it as a resource created inside Heat engine.  Persisting properties into the resource_data table could harm the maintainability of the code, e.g. you need to identify which properties should go into that table, IIUC."}, {'account_id': 8289, 'date': '2014-11-12 08:05:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-11-12 08:08:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

commit_message:
Implement 'InstanceId' for AutoScalingGroup

Implement 'InstanceId' for AWS::AutoScaling::AutoScalingGroup
resource to be comcompatible with AWSCloudFormation.
Add then user can specific 'InstanceId' property if he want to
create an Auto Scaling group that uses an existing instance
instead of a launch configuration.

Specification blueprint implement-instanceid-for-autoscalinggroup

Change-Id: Ia1182942fc78b36313ac515ba3e60154c5b38f3d

- gate-heat-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/76/135076/2/check/gate-heat-specs-docs/96c88f9/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 21s'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2014-11-17 21:54:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Just a question, IME nested stacks are already pretty well hidden, to the point that I've had to put the "nested" hint in resource-show links output, and add --show-nested to stack_list.

Given they're hidden by default anyway, I'm not sure what this gains us, we'll have hidden by default, and, uh, really hidden as an option?

Is there part of this requirement we're not capturing here, like that the operator defined provider resource should be immutable, or at least not directly modifiable by the end user?'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2014-11-17 21:58:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Steven no, this isn't for provider resources but for top-level stacks. Basically, the provider wants to do things with orchestration "under the covers" and not have those stacks show up in the list of things the user chose to orchestrate themselves. I suppose we could have some mechanism by which the provider could create "administrative" stacks in which the provider owns the stack, but the user owns the resources, but that seems like a *lot* more work IMO.'}, {'account_id': 7253, 'date': '2014-11-17 22:16:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Steven, this would be for top-level stacks that are created by the cloud provider.  They would be created as a part of the server creation process, separate from any user templates.  They would even be created if a user manually spun up a Nova server without Heat.  It's a way to help move some of the orchestration out of Nova plug-ins and into Heat."}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2014-11-18 02:26:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

So ... it is more of a 'privileged' stack than of a 'hidden' one?

I like this idea considering that there are many admin-only APIs (e.g. flavor) which now can be orchestrated by an operator, using Heat.  We may need to widen the Heat scope which previously was stated to be about user-facing APIs only?"}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2014-11-18 09:04:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

Randall, Jason: Thanks for the feedback, removing my objection, but I'm not ready to +2 this yet as I've still got some concerns (or, quite possibly, misunderstandings):

Here's a quote from the spec:

> For example, creation of a Nova server might include,by default, creation and configuration of a network, subnet, port, and security group.

This is the *exact* use case provider resources solve, so can you clarify why you can't just use provider templates defined in the global environment?

That, to me, seems a much more obvious solution, and it will actually be less confusing for users because it's the same as the standard provider resource interface.

Evidently, I'm still missing something about this use-case - why hidden top-level stacks rather than provider resources, given that Randall says the stacks will be owned by the user?

Is the idea that they're hidden so the user can't modify them, or the network resources are somehow secret?  If that's the case then I think proper separation is the way to go, since other than obfuscating the stack identity this solution doesn't provide any separation at all (if the user somehow gets the hidden stack name or ID, they still own it).

Further clarification would be great, thanks! :)"}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2014-11-18 09:14:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> They would even be created if a user manually spun up a Nova server without Heat. It's a way to help move some of the orchestration out of Nova plug-ins and into Heat.

Can you expand on this a bit?  I'm not familiar with what hook nova has that could trigger a stack create?

I guess this requirement makes things a little clearer, perhaps we could add details of how this will work to the spec as an example use-case?"}, {'account_id': 7253, 'date': '2014-11-18 15:52:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

>> They would even be created if a user manually spun up a Nova server without Heat. It's a way to help move some of the orchestration out of Nova plug-ins and into Heat.

> Can you expand on this a bit? I'm not familiar with what hook nova has that could trigger a stack create?

The "server create" function in this hypothetical cloud portal would make a call to Heat instead of Nova.  Heat would then orchestrate the Nova server create call along with all the other calls that are currently being done in Nova plug-ins and then wire it all up.

The reason these stacks would be hidden is because Heat is no longer a purely user-facing orchestration program.  If users started seeing these automated stacks appear in the portal every time they created a new server, it would be very confusing.

I'll expand on this use-case in the spec.  Thanks for your feedback.'}, {'account_id': 9189, 'date': '2014-11-18 17:02:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7253, 'date': '2014-11-18 18:28:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 12606, 'date': '2014-11-18 18:43:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Jason,

In general I agree with the proposal, and I like that it is a pretty straightforward solution.

Couple of possible enhancements:

- On stack-update it should be allowed to "hide" or "show" stacks.
- What do you think of adding a top-level "hidden" attribute in HOT templates? This would provide a default visibility setting, which you can override from the API.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-11-18 18:51:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-heat-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/76/135076/3/check/gate-heat-specs-docs/26d767c/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 26s'}, {'account_id': 7253, 'date': '2014-11-18 21:37:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi Miguel,

That's an interesting idea, but I'd rather not include that functionality as it doesn't fit our use-case.  Also, including this type of user-preference in the template would make them less portable."}, {'account_id': 12606, 'date': '2014-11-18 22:52:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Well, okay, not sure I agree, but that's fine, there is always a chance to make improvements after the first implementation is out.

FWIW, I see the "hidden" attribute of a stack as a first-class attribute, in my opinion it should be editable.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2014-11-19 11:05:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Miguel Grinberg: FWIW I see this as a property of the instantiation of a stack, not part of the definition, as such IMHO it should be an API option not something defined in the template (similar to timeout).

Just my opinion, but that, I think, is the convention we've mostly adhered to thusfar."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2014-11-19 11:09:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Ok, thanks for the clarification, the "hypothetical cloud portal" use-case makes sense to me, and does seem justified vs provider resources.

If you do another iteration, it might me worth mentioning that use-case in the spec.'}, {'account_id': 13323, 'date': '2014-11-19 15:59:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9189, 'date': '2014-11-19 16:02:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2014-11-20 08:15:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I posted a question inline, there for the -1.

I am perfectly leaning towards +2 if that inline question gets answered, or addressed by a small update to the spec.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2014-11-20 09:09:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I am fine with the automatic prefix. Should this be captured in the spec, or is everyone ok with just getting it implemented in the patches?'}, {'account_id': 7253, 'date': '2014-11-21 14:35:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thomas, I will update the spec.'}, {'account_id': 7253, 'date': '2014-11-21 15:20:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 7253, 'date': '2014-11-21 15:21:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7385, 'date': '2014-11-21 15:26:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I'm a bit underwhelmed by that feature. It seems the only use case is "hide them from the user portal", which you could achieve by using a well known prefix in your stack name for example.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-11-21 15:29:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified-1

- gate-heat-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/76/135076/5/check/gate-heat-specs-docs/02226a7/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 38s'}, {'account_id': 7253, 'date': '2014-11-21 17:47:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Thomas H., doing it that way would mess up pagination.  Also, others may have similar use cases, and making this feature available upstream would save them the effort of implementing downstream workarounds.'}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2014-11-21 18:17:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2014-11-24 01:41:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

Seems harmless enough.'}, {'account_id': 9189, 'date': '2014-11-24 17:57:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2014-11-24 18:09:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

I forget the policy on specs. Is it 2 +2 before +A or ...?'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2014-11-24 21:05:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Keith explained this to me at Summit and I'm fine with it in principle. Some things to maybe consider:

- I don't love 'hidden' as a name... maybe we could bikeshed some other ideas ;)
- Would it be worth implementing this as part of a more generic tagging mechanism?"}, {'account_id': 9189, 'date': '2014-11-24 21:13:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I actually like the tagging mechanism idea better.  And it would solve the first of Zane's concerns by proxy, as the name of the tag that should or should not be included in the list is up to the provider."}, {'account_id': 7230, 'date': '2014-11-24 21:56:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10487, 'date': '2014-11-25 06:11:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Nice idea.'}, {'account_id': 7253, 'date': '2014-11-25 16:26:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Tagging is an interesting idea.  I could see adding a "tag" parameter to stack-list that resulted in only stacks with that particular tag being shown.  Otherwise, with no tag parameter, it would show all stacks.  To satisfy this use-case, we could make a "user" tag and filter by that tag by default from the UI.  However, API users would see the admin stacks by default in stack-list.  Whereas, with hidden stacks, they would have to explicitly show them.'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2014-11-25 16:53:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Other than possibly having yet another "metadata" to be consistent with the other OS services, the tags idea seems fine to me as well. It would also fit in with the meta cataloging service work in Glance. In the end, I'm not fussed either way as long as we can query/filter on tags at the db layer to make sure we don't get odd pagination results.'}, {'account_id': 7253, 'date': '2014-11-25 17:21:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

To handle the case I mentioned in my last comment where users could see a different list of stacks in the UI and API, I think we'd have to add an "auto-hide" config option, which specifies a list of tags that shouldn't be shown by default in stack-list.

Maybe we should implement hidden (invisible? :) stacks now and add tagging later on if/when it is really needed.  Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2014-11-25 22:34:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Code-Review

Jason, wouldn't some tags just be set by policy enforcement? So the operator would say "you must have role X to view stacks with the following tag"? Then the UI and cli would be the same.'}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2014-11-26 01:23:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I was thinking that this is about privileged stacks that allows users to use admin-only resources/APIs, but it is not.  Now it reads more about permission or access control.  Each stack has permission bits indicating who (owner/user/others/...) can read(list/show), write(update/delete) a stack.'}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2014-11-27 12:46:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@Qiming: this is not for privileged stack, as far as I understand. Use case would be, for example, that one wants to create not only a server but also configure networking and storage (kind of a more advanced server template) and use heat to do this. But it would be good not show all the many resulting stacks, but only those explicitly created via the orchestration view.

I thought about general tagging too, but the thing with tags is that interpretation depends on the views or users using the tags. So having a UI view filter out stack with a "hidden" tags would be by pure convention, whereas a stack hidden via an API flag is "really" hidden.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2014-11-27 14:20:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> Jason, wouldn't some tags just be set by policy enforcement? So the operator would say "you must have role X to view stacks with the following tag"? Then the UI and cli would be the same.

I'm pretty sure our current policy implementation wouldn't support this, because it applies the policy at the point of receiving the request.  

So you could probably deny requests which explicitly ask for a *only* a specific tag, but you can't apply role-based filtering on the data in the response, in the case where no tag is provided (e.g the generic "list stacks" case, which is driving the requirement behind this spec)

Not saying it's impossible, just that it's inconsistent with the current openstack policy model AIUI.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2014-11-27 14:33:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

I think this looks OK - holding off +2 until we reach consensus on the tags comments.'}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2014-11-27 15:12:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@Thomas, thanks for the explanation.  Absolutely no doubt the tagging approach would work for now.  What I'm concerned is about the direction this work is leading us to.  Currently it is about the visibility of some stacks to some users/tools, in future, there might be requests that some stacks are read-only to some users, i.e. resources created from these operators-owned stacks might be referenced in other "normal" stacks, possibly serve as part of their environment.  However, those users are disallowed to update, delete the stack or any resources created by them.  What I'm suggesting is to mark a stack with a permission string, for example, rather than a tag only for hiding.  I'm not advocating a huge access control design which may take forever to land.  And... we all know, once code is there, it will take huge efforts to change it, no fun.'}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2014-11-27 15:38:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@Qiming: something like linux file permissions for stacks?'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2014-11-27 15:57:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Just to be clear, as spec'd, these would not be operator owned, but rather owned by the user as any other stack. The goal is to simply be able to easily separate them from the ones the user creates explicitly. While a lot of the discussion is good and does tend to suggest other interesting use cases, my concern is we're over-complicating a fairly straight-forward requirement for the sake of possible future requirements. Creating operator-owned stacks while maintaining user visibility into the created resources sounds pretty complicated and the associated ACL work sounds much more involved considering the original requirement."}, {'account_id': 10487, 'date': '2014-12-03 10:51:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

kindly add changes for the python-heat client and heat CLI to accommodate this changes.

Also is this flag should be controlled with Keystone RBAC policy?

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2014-12-09 22:40:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Yeah, I agree with Randall that this shouldn't veer into permissions territory. But I see lots of great discussion about tags.

If we implemented tags would we want them to be just straight-up strings, or key-value pairs? (I suspect the latter.)

It seems like it would be pretty easy to e.g. tag all stacks created through the API with {source: api} by default (maybe provider resources could have {source: heat}, and other applications like Murano could be encouraged to use the source tag to identify themselves). Then in stack-list we would by default filter on {source: api}, but of course the user could override that. Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2014-12-09 23:43:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Zane, that sounds interesting as well. We could also add a configuration option for operators so that they could customize the stack tags/values that are hidden by default. Still a little more complex, but tags do seem to be the popular alternative.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2014-12-10 00:38:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

randallburt++'}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2014-12-10 09:04:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Ok, so I like the tagging idea now. Key is really what Zane brought up, i.e. that a special tag (or a configurable set of tags as Randall suggested) result in hiding the stack by default in stack-list. If that is well-documented, then it's a nice solution. My original concern with tags was that their interpretation is completely up to the client, but this new twist resolve this concern.

So +1 on this new idea - and I am converting my +2 on this current spec to a +1 in favor of seeing a little re-write for the tag bases solution."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2014-12-10 09:23:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@Kanagaraj Manickam	

> Also is this flag should be controlled with Keystone RBAC policy?

As I mentioned previously, I don't think the RBAC model is the place to define what is hidden by default (if that's what you mean?), it will need to be a list of tags in heat.conf."}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2014-12-10 11:01:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Since this is about flexible tagging which can be extended to other usage scenarios, I don't see a problem with it now."}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2014-12-12 03:35:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

-1 until updated to the tagging idea.'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2014-12-12 10:05:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

I also do like the tagging approach. One more probable use case I've encountered recently is related with Sahara. Sahara already uses Heat for its internal orchestration, and currently when I instantiate a OS::Sahara::Cluster resource in my template, I as a user also see the underlying stack created by Sahara. Would be nice if operators of Sahara service also could add such specific tags to their internally created stacks to hide them from common user by default. That also might concern Trove when it moves to using Heat orchestration internally."}, {'account_id': 9189, 'date': '2014-12-19 15:50:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-12-19 15:56:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified+1

(2 comments)

Some minor comments inline, but LGTM otherwise.'}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2014-12-20 01:06:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Stack Tags

Allow the creation of stacks with specific tags that can be used by the
cloud provider as a means to hide stacks created as a part of other
services operations.

Co-Authored-By: Anderson Mesquita <andersonvom@gmail.com>
Specification: blueprint stack-tags
Change-Id: I41b2940433bd20c1f3140334babcee762c740560
DocImpact

commit_message:
Store introspection result in the local database

node_cache.pop_node renamed to find_node as it's no longer purging
anything from database.

node_cache.NodeInfo.finished was added to signal processing result

Change-Id: Icc85752005ea8e894c0aa3e5f4458136dbe587b2
Implements: blueprint get-status-api

@Dina, I did not know that. I once learnt that bp can be created anyone in the openstack community. (as I found in the launchpad) 

Maybe we not talked about same bp.'}, {'account_id': 3012, 'date': '2014-12-26 09:20:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Kai Qiang Wu, that's the workflow Ceilometer team agreed on not to produce new and new (and not always realistic or needed) BPs on LP. LP cannot delete BPs if they are not approved, etc. - they are all there forever. To avoid this situation we've all agreed on spec proposal -> spec approval -> BP creation workflow - Ceilometer team was really suffering from unrealistic BPs being created - and never implemented. Technically all of us - any OpenStack contributor can create the BP on LP, but we try to follow ourselves defined workflow here."}, {'account_id': 7052, 'date': '2014-12-29 18:11:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-01-06 11:54:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Verified

commit_message:
Add help text for 'host' parameter in neutron.conf file

This patch adds the help text for 'host' parameter in
neutron.conf which is presently missing and updates
the neutron/common/config.py accordingly

Change-Id: Iddfc9c44b3fae95cbae1cfe1142c3d3a92749799
Closes-bug: #1406052

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-11-09 15:02:51.000000000', 'message': 'Metadata service: remove check for the instance object type

The method now receives an instance object. There is no longer
any need to convert it to an instance object.

Change-Id: I87fc41cc9dd2c2576a75f343817558849f6f1413
'}, {'created': '2014-11-13 07:27:12.000000000', 'message': 'Metadata service: remove check for the instance object type

commit_message:
Metadata service: remove check for the instance object type

The method now receives an instance object. There is no longer
any need to convert it to an instance object.

Change-Id: I87fc41cc9dd2c2576a75f343817558849f6f1413

commit_message:
Add urllib3 for glanceclient fix

Change https://review.openstack.org/#/c/137748 which fixes a HTTPS bug,
removes requests.packages.urllib3 and uses urllib3 instead.

Further information on why urllib3 should be used over the requests
version: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/122993/

Change-Id: I35cadcc64e38a063b4f7b78daccf06334e4b4585

subject: Handle HTTP 415 in rest_client

commit_message:
Handle HTTP 415 in rest_client

If HTTP 415 ("Unsupported Media Type") is returned then,
rest_client responds with an "UnexpectedResponseCode" exception.

Tempest always send request with supported media type and that's
why 415 did not happen.
But as rest_client is on the way to be part of tempest-lib,
its better to handle 415 and raise appropriate error.

This patch handle HTTP 415 error and raise 'InvalidContentType'.

Change-Id: I72690aab7afd8e68f054f31315a8b1576a7ec9c4
Closes-Bug: #1407140

commit_message:
/etc/default/neutron-server file is only on Ubuntu packages

The /etc/default/neutron-server file is only present in Ubuntu packages,
not in Debian.
Let's change the fact to detect Ubuntu instead of Debian operating
system.

Change-Id: Iac73b475bfc8ac7f9f97a858ab836a4d07afac5f

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Gerrit_Workflow"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-18 16:38:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

- gate-ironic-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/51/100951/5/check/gate-ironic-specs-python27/f536f53 : SUCCESS in 51s
- gate-ironic-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/51/100951/5/check/gate-ironic-specs-docs/1ed3b24/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 50s'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2014-06-18 21:06:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Thank you for the proposal, Nisha!

I think this is a good feature, and it is inline with the direction the project is going. However, I'm going to -1 this for two reasons.

First, your proposal is specific to the iLO driver, which has not been approved or merged yet. I appreciate the forward-looking proposal which communicates your plans. That's really great to see. 

Second, the APIs for node introspection need to be general enough that they support our generic IPMI drivers (to the degree that is possible), other vendor's drivers (eg, SeaMicro), as well as in-band methods planned by the IPA driver. So I'd like those teams to have time to review this and weigh in.

So, if this is a specific feature of the iLO driver, please update the title and introductory paragraph to indicate that. On the other hand, if it's a generic feature (which I think is your intent) then it should discuss how other drivers will implement the same feature.

Regards,
Devananda"}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2014-06-19 05:27:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Deva,

Thanks for the comment.
I hope the iLO driver is approved for merging soon. :)

The proposal is a generic proposal. The ManagementInterface() method discover_hardware_properties() can be implemented by other drivers to give the same functionality. Do i need to discuss /investigate each of the drivers how the functionality can be implemented?

The functionality is proposed to be implemented by iLO driver but the approach is generic. The filtering for driver doesnt happen at the API layer, while it happens over the driver/conductor side. 

Regards
Nisha'}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2014-06-19 07:36:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Deva,

By iLO driver i hope you meant the iLO power driver.
Once that is approved this feature can go in. correct?

I spoke to k4n0 on IRC for Seamicro side review, he said he is no longer working on seamicro but he would have a look at the proposal. 

Could you connect to seamicro and IPA guys for them to review the proposal?

Regards
Nisha'}, {'account_id': 7589, 'date': '2014-06-19 16:06:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Hi Nisha,
   Thanks for the design spec. There was a similar blueprint before for IPMI https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/ipminode-auto-discovery, but it was put on shelf for the following reasons:
1. There is no way to automatically tell which mac to use for installation without booting up the node. Getting all the macs into the node table is not good for deployment. 
2. Disk inventory is tricky and unreliable. It seems not possible to retrieve disk layout/capacity only with IPMI (AFAIK, in the general case).
That being said, I think it is still very useful to let the user see the inventory info from the bmc. User can choose manually register the node via node-create command or let the IPA does the auto discovery in-band. 
So I suggest that we add a new function in the ManagementInterface called get_hardware_inventory that returns the properties you have mentioned in the spec. And also add a CLI "ironic node-get-hw-inv <node_uuid>" to display these properties. Just my 2 cents.'}, {'account_id': 7589, 'date': '2014-06-19 16:09:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Code-Review

why my comments do not wrap correctly? :) Can anyone help?'}, {'account_id': 7589, 'date': '2014-06-19 16:10:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2014-06-19 16:43:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi linggao,

Thanks for the comments.
1. Populating all the node properties at node-create and node-update is possible even without OS provisioned on the baremetal.
2. Populating the baremetal MACs in the properties info is a part of discovering node properties and populating them in properties field.
3. The question whether the port/mac address can be used for provisioning is suggested through an option in node-create and will not be done automatically unless user specify the option.
4. I was thinking to populate the extra field of the port created for a MAC address with the information whether the MAC address is in disabled/PXE Boot/iSCSI state. I think the PXE state MAC address can be chosen for deployment(I am not sure though). It can avoid to create port for MAC addresses which are in disabled state. 

Let me know the opinion.

-Nisha'}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2014-06-19 16:48:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi linggao,

I didnt proposed a generic API for hardware discovery as IPA is also planning to do node properties discovery at node-create and not through a generic CLI. However, if required i can propose a new CLI.

By disk inventory , you mean the disk layout? or the disk properties? The disk/storage properties can be discovered without the need of an OS.

-Nisha'}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2014-06-19 16:56:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi,


The disk details example as returned by iLO is:

<PHYSICAL_DRIVE>
 <LABEL VALUE = "Port 1I Box 1 Bay 3"/>
 <STATUS VALUE = "OK"/>
 <SERIAL_NUMBER VALUE = "6TA0N3SZ0000B231CYDT"/>
 <MODEL VALUE = "EH0072FAWJA"/>
 <CAPACITY VALUE = "68 GB"/>
 <LOCATION VALUE = "Port 1I Box 1 Bay 3"/>
 <FW_VERSION VALUE = "HPDH"/>
 <DRIVE_CONFIGURATION VALUE = "Configured"/>
 </PHYSICAL_DRIVE>


We can get similar data for logical drive too through iLO.
I think even IPMI should be able to get above information.

If you do not mean above data, please explain what do you mean by disk inventory.

Regards
Nisha'}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2014-06-22 16:51:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-22 16:51:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(15 comments)

I have commented on several items which I am concerned about inline.

I also feel this spec should be split into a general proposal of the new APIs and new control flow without a specific implementation, and then a separate proposal for the iLO implementation thereof. I think this will simplify the conversation among the interested parties (other vendors who will want to support this feature) and make adding the iLO support for discovery much easier once the overall feature is agreed upon.

Thanks!
Devananda'}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2014-06-26 18:40:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-06-26 18:41:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(13 comments)

Hi! We had a discussion about this feature here on the summit[1]. So pity you're not with us here! Let me try to communicate back what we agreed on.

Main suggestions is to have new node provisioning states "discovering", "discovery_failed" and target provisioning state "discovered". This solves problem of signaling success/unsuccess. To account for OOB vs IB methods, I suggest that discover_hardware_properties does not return anything and updates everything on it's own. This makes stating inventory structure in this spec no longer required. 

E.g. in case of in-band discovery, it will set provisioning_state to discovering, target state to discovered, invoke in-band discovery tool and exit. In-band discovery tool will set state to "discovered" after some time. There should be also time out for discovery operation imposed by the conductor (all this actually reminds how deploy is done today).

To sum it up, here are suggested changes:
- Add new provision states "discovering", "discovered", "discovery failed"
- Before calling to the management interface, node state is set to "discovering", target state - to "discovered"
- On discovery failure node state is set to "discovery failed" and "last_error" is updated
- On success, state is set to "discovered" by the management interface implementation, then back to "no state" (IIRC by status update periodic call, not sure here)
- It should be a requirement that node is not provisioned when starting discovery (which is quite obvious but should be enforced)
- If the new management interface (or something external) does not set provision state to "discovered", discovery times out and state is set to "discovery failed"
- New management interface should do node update and port create, there's no need to agree on inventory format

Ideas for future enhancements (please don't implement here for now):
- Make it guess the driver
- Allow user to confirm discovered data before applying

Hoe it makes sense to you, feel free to ask any questions here (I'm not on IRC due to the summit, but will try to answer).

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/kilo-ironic-understanding-hardware'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2014-11-06 15:09:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 34:

And thank you for your hard work on this spec, much appreciated! :)'}, {'account_id': 4573, 'date': '2014-11-06 17:47:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 34:

Hi again, some more updates from the Friday discussion on the summit.

We decided to rethink how our state machine for a node works. The most important for you is the following part: there will be new state "discovering", which means node being in the process of discovery. There will be a separate "wait" flag on node, meaning that in-band discovery by 3rd party is going on. After "discovering", node should be moved to a new "init" state, meaning "node has all the scheduling information, but may be still not ready for scheduling real load on it". Everything else is the same as in my previous comment here.

That unfortunately means that your work on this spec is partly blocked by this new state reform. Anyway please feel free to update this spec addressing all the remaining comments and jump into the IRC meeting (not sure if there will be one this week) to get more updates.'}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2014-11-11 08:33:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 34:

Hi Dmitry,

>>>After "discovering", node should be moved to a new "init" state, meaning "node has all the scheduling information, but may be still not ready for scheduling real load on it".

- "init" will be for provision_state? or target_provision_state?
- When do we say the node is ready for scheduling?
- properties discovering can be done at any point of time after node is registered after its supplied with mandatory fields like ip address, password etc. 
- Before starting deploy the init state shall be cleared off to None? As of today, when deploy starts the provision_state is None. Or the deploy drivers shall be modified to search for state as "init" before starting deploy? I think it shall be latter.

Let me know your opinion.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2014-11-11 10:40:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 34:

Thank you for your questions. Actually answers will be provided in an appropriate spec (which I'm also looking forward), here's short version:

> "init" will be for provision_state? or target_provision_state?

I'm afraid to confuse you here. Most of the states can be both, I think (and not 100% sure right now), that "INIT" will be target state during discovery, then become a provision state.

> When do we say the node is ready for scheduling?

There will be a new state "available", replacing "no state" existing now. To move from "init" to "available" node may need to undergo several long tasks, like building raid or wiping the hard drive.

> properties discovering can be done at any point of time after node is registered after its supplied with mandatory fields like ip address, password etc.

I didn't quite got the question. There's not point in keeping a node for a long time in a undefined state.

> Before starting deploy the init state shall be cleared off to None? As of today, when deploy starts the provision_state is None. Or the deploy drivers shall be modified to search for state as "init" before starting deploy? I think it shall be latter.

State "None" aka "no state" will be dropped in favor of new "available" state.

Your spec should only be concerned about "discovering" and "init" states, please wait for the other specs to clarify the whole state reform.

Hope that helps.'}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2014-11-11 19:17:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 35.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-11-11 19:22:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 35: Verified+1

That aside, I suggest adding an option for timeout as part of this spec. That's how it was in my spec (Deva suggested moving it here):

 * Implement timeouts for discovery. There should be a periodic task in the
  conductor, checking that every mapped node is not in DISCOVERING state for
  more then ``discovery_timeout``.
 * New option: ``discovery_timeout`` (integer, in seconds, default to 1 hour)
  with the amount of time after which discovery is considered to be failed and
  node is moved to DISCOVERYFAIL state"}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2014-11-25 08:41:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 45: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2014-11-25 16:56:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 46.'}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2014-11-25 16:59:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 46:

(1 comment)

So, this is looking good. I was thinking a lot about discovery (again!) this week and I have a couple of things to discuss.

1. About rebasing away from state machine. Actually it starts to make some sense to me. The state machine is expected to take a lot of time and effort. So my personally IMO (and it does not represent any substantial part of the core team) is that you could rebase it on master and just mention introducing 2 new state: DISCOVERING and DISCOVERED (no INIT, because it's part of the state machine). Please do not take any actions for now! I'm not sure anyone will agree with it, but you're welcome to raise this topic on ML and/or the next meeting.

2. I'm not really sure it should be in the ManagementInterace. It's not managing anything :) Also believe or not, some folks want to use in-band discovery with ILO driver. What about a separate IntrospectionInterface (or DiscoveryInterface)? We may also discuss it with wider audience."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2014-11-27 09:30:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 46:

Added both topics to the meeting https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/Ironic'}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2014-11-27 10:12:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 46:

Yes Wan-yen. 
iLO refernce implementation can do this and is intended to do that. In that case we will not need https://review.openstack.org/#/c/103007. If reviewers dont agree then we can have these under the https://review.openstack.org/#/c/103007.'}, {'account_id': 10202, 'date': '2014-12-15 08:17:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 57:

(2 comments)

The spec and API look good to me.  I want to point out that "support boot mode(s)" is also required by scheduler in order to support multiple boot modes, namely bios,uefi and secure boot.  Therefore, drivers capable of discvoering this proerpty should also do so and update the discovered "supported boot mode(s)" to node property.'}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2014-12-15 08:29:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 58.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-12-15 08:34:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 58: Verified+1

commit_message:
Discover node properties using new target inspect with
node-set-provision-state

Implements : blueprint ironic-node-properties-discovery

commit_message:
Remove AccountClientCustomizedHeader class

AccountClientCustomizedHeader contains list_account_containers and
request(). However, they are almost duplicated with AccountClient and
we can use AccountClient instead.
This patch removes AccountClientCustomizedHeader and makes some tests
use AccountClient instead.

Change-Id: I0d933440f788e0d111e6e4c9b883e736a7d08362

commit_message:
Add possibility to create lots of shares in parallel for tempest

Test suite located in module
contrib/tempest/tempest/api/share/admin/test_multi_backend.py
creates 2 shares without waiting for "available" status and then waits for
status. In this case "retry" functionality is not used.

Add method 'create_shares' to base class that does parallel share
creation with recreation as it is done with single request. And use this
method in mentioned test module.

Change-Id: I1314c9494a547314cd9bb9b03323470d58956fac
Closes-Bug: #1406770
