(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2014-11-14 12:09:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(23 comments)

Lots and lots of pedantry for you!

Can I rest assured that this spec replaces https://review.openstack.org/#/c/100278 and  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/93613

Finally, one more note.
This spec addresses the case for using VTEP-capable hardware switches to interconnect tenant networks with 'external' networks where external should not be intended as a neutron network but a network not managed by neutron.

This spec is NOT about using such hardware for doing ToR VxLAN offloading for multi-segment networks (where vlans are used within racks). I hope this is correct, otherwise we'll have to revise everything."}, {'account_id': 8190, 'date': '2014-11-14 12:48:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Coming back to my previous comment about permissions and looking at the other blueprints.

I see that https://review.openstack.org/#/c/87825/ takes care of permissions and it has actually done significant progress although not merged in juno. I am not sure of the status of this, but I clearly see a possibility of combining ideas and coming up with a single mechanism to deal with physical attachment points (whether L2 gateways or anything else). There is lots of work that has been done there already: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/97173/

Wouldn't that make sense ? There is also the ironic work that is in similar directions.

I just feel we have too many parallel open threads for the same or similar problems and we should try to consolidate on a common model."}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2014-12-03 01:19:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2014-11-13 12:14:50.000000000', 'message': 'L2 gateway as a service

This blueprint is an umbrella blueprint to support different
ways of automatically provisioning a hardware top-of-rack (ToR)
switch through OpenStack Neutron.

Change-Id: I1f836bef00a95de3232c1a53e7837e5d5ac136c0
'}, {'created': '2014-11-18 09:09:55.000000000', 'message': 'L2 gateway as a service

This blueprint l2gateway is an umbrella blueprint to provision
a hardware top-of-rack (ToR) switch through OpenStack Neutron.
This way, overlay networks like VXLAN can be extended into
VLANs which are external to the cloud environment.

Change-Id: I1f836bef00a95de3232c1a53e7837e5d5ac136c0
'}, {'created': '2014-11-20 12:36:42.000000000', 'message': "Define L2 gateway API

This blueprint l2gateway describes a solution to extend
overlay networks into VLANs which are external to the
cloud environment via a gateway, either software or hardware.
The spec tries to combine the needs of other existing proposals
(see below) to come up with a set of APIs that will address
everyone's needs:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/100278
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/93613
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/87825

The current spec discloses one implementation using the standard
OVSDB hardware_vtep schema.

Change-Id: I1f836bef00a95de3232c1a53e7837e5d5ac136c0
"}, {'created': '2014-11-22 15:04:44.000000000', 'message': "Define L2 gateway API

This blueprint l2gateway describes a solution to extend
overlay networks into VLANs which are external to the
cloud environment via a gateway, either software or hardware.
The spec tries to combine the needs of other existing proposals
to come up with a set of APIs that will address everyone's needs.

Co-Authored-By: Isaku Yamahata <yamahata.review@gmail.com>
                (Launchpad ID - yamahata)

Change-Id: I1f836bef00a95de3232c1a53e7837e5d5ac136c0
"}, {'created': '2014-12-03 14:26:58.000000000', 'message': 'Define L2 gateway API

This blueprint l2gateway describes a solution to extend
overlay networks into VLANs which are external to the
cloud environment via a gateway, either software or hardware.
The spec proposes a set of APIs that will abstract
a gateway into logical resource(s) and then manage
them.

Co-Authored-By: Isaku Yamahata <yamahata.review@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Define L2 gateway API

This blueprint l2gateway describes a solution to extend
overlay networks into VLANs which are external to the
cloud environment via a gateway, either software or hardware.
The spec proposes a set of APIs that will abstract
a gateway into logical resource(s) and then manage
them.

Co-Authored-By: Isaku Yamahata <yamahata.review@gmail.com>
                (Launchpad ID - yamahata)

Change-Id: I1f836bef00a95de3232c1a53e7837e5d5ac136c0

commit_message:
L2 gateway API implementation

The blueprint l2gwovsdb discloses one implementation of the
L2 gateway APIs described in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/134179/
using the standard OVSDB hardware_vtep schema.

Co-Authored-By: Selvakumar S <selvakumar-s2@hp.com>
                (Launchpad ID: selvakumar-s2)

Change-Id: Ifaf4ed0ef2f9f988343b7208fe07a029960194a7

This is just moving code around - no need to block this for the FF so strictly IMHO'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2014-09-02 14:56:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

The blueprint is no longer in juno, as per ttx's email on the FF process, because non of the patches in the blueprint has any +2s. its all to prioritise getting blueprints completed.

In this case, if we remove the association with the blueprint, it can go in as a refactor. Happy to remove the -2 if that bit of the commit message goes.

Given it will probably clash a lot in the gate, it might be better to merge this just after juno-3, so we don't block all the features trying to make it in right now.

But thats just want it looks like from where I am sat. I am probably not seeing something."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2014-09-03 09:44:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> In this case, if we remove the association with the
> blueprint, it can go in as a refactor. Happy to remove the
> -2 if that bit of the commit message goes.

IMHO the link to the blueprint / spec is useful design information for anyone looking at this change later. If we're willing to merge it as a refactor we should do so regardless of whether it lists a blueprint in the commit message. Removing a link to a useful design doc just to satisfy an arbitrary process is just crazy."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-09-09 10:48:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified-1

commit_message:
libvirt: introduce new 'Host' class to manage the connection

Move all the code related to obtaining a new libvirt connection
out into a new 'Host' class. This covers the initial connection
attempt, testing of the connection, handling of connection close
events and handling of lifecycle events.

The appropriate tests are also moved out into a new HostTestCase
class

Blueprint: libvirt-driver-class-refactor
Change-Id: I64e84c4ed7b275632ef2ce3fa6e4be4c0ee8235a

subject: Fix the GET's response code when there is a missing segment in LO

@Samuel, Thank you for your review. 
 
I think you pointed out the code (the start_response at L1310) to decide the response code so I put a validation for first segment in the timing b/w L1306 and L1310.

- Response.__call__()
1306         app_iter = self._response_iter(self.app_iter, self._body)
1307         if 'location' in self.headers and \
1308                 not env.get('swift.leave_relative_location'):
1309             self.location = self.absolute_location()
1310         start_response(self.status, self.headers.items())"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2014-11-25 12:59:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified-1

(2 comments)

So, this seems to do what it says, and 409 is certainly better than 500.

I'd like to see this extended to DLOs if at all possible. I took a crack at it here https://gist.github.com/smerritt/05967640a773f17a3604 and it actually turned out pretty nice. It prompted me to get rid of a nasty little circular reference that the DLO middleware was using to compute Content-Length.

My only concern is with the treatment of an empty manifest as an error condition, but since SLOs can't be empty anyway or else the PUT fails, it's not really a big deal I guess. I can always submit a patch for it later.

Feel free to take as much or as little of the linked patch as you want and apply it here. If you don't, I'll probably end up submitting it myself, so no big deal either way.

How would you like to proceed?"}, {'account_id': 12193, 'date': '2014-12-05 08:58:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Samuel, Thank you for the review. I wanna try to add your code in this patch. But today I don't have enough time to do it so I will read your code in next week. the handle_request in catch_errors.py calls _app_call then execute next in it. If there is an exception, it is catched in the handle_request. this is only for first iteration.

OK I now understand your argument w.r.t. the exception logging. Thanks.

I have reviewed the tests and  became aware of one significant issue: in dlo.py the first segment validation check is performed for both HEAD and GET requests - in the case of HEAD it is not necessary and introduces a GET to the object server. Compare with the slo.py - in slo, the response to a HEAD is returned before the app_iter is constructed.

I suggest a change here: http://paste.openstack.org/show/153838/

what do you think?

Also, it would be nice if the tests asserted that the expected log messages occur.'}, {'account_id': 12193, 'date': '2014-12-24 09:38:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Fix the GET's response code when there is a missing segment in LO

This patch changes the response code from Internal Server Error to
Conflict when there is a missing segment and the position is first.

Co-Authored-By: Samuel Merritt <sam@swiftstack.com>
Closes-Bug: #1386568
Change-Id: Iac175b4dc6ac9081436738697a27fe669acce0eb
